Award.AwardTitle: Magneto-Active Elastomers: Homogenization, Instabilities and Relaxation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the research program of the Principal Investigator on the mathematical modeling of soft composite materials responsive to magnetic fields. Magneto-active elastomers (MAEs) are composite materials consisting of nearly rigid, magnetically susceptible particles embedded in a soft, magnetically insensitive elastomer matrix (a rubber-like material). MAEs exhibit field-dependent strains (changes in length) and changes in stiffness. However, the strains that have been achieved experimentally to date are still relatively small (on the order of 1%). The reason for these small strains can be traced back to the nature of the forces between the particles. Large particle concentrations are required to generate strong forces, but large concentrations also lead to large overall stiffness for the composite material, which, in turn, tends to reduce the overall strain. Generating large actuation strains and stresses in MAEs for successful application as "artificial muscles" requires novel strategies. This project will be concerned with the possible excitation of a particular instability in a certain class of MAEs that will allow the generation of large strains by means of externally applied magnetic fields. The work will result in novel and highly efficient multi-scale, multi-physics modeling techniques of broad application.

The development of constitutive models for MAEs undergoing such field-generated instabilities will require the use and appropriate generalization of several powerful and sophisticated mathematical tools. First, nonlinear homogenization methods will be developed to obtain estimates for the macroscopic "pre-bifurcation" response. For this purpose, a partial decoupling of the magnetic and mechanical energies will be implemented by means of a variational statement involving a purely magnetic problem in the deformed configuration, as determined by the unknown particle rotations, and a purely mechanical problem with prescribed torques on the particles. The average particle rotations will then be obtained by minimizing the total magneto-elastic energy of the system. The resulting constitutive model is expected to lose strong ellipticity, and to lead to the development of domain mesostructures, when the magnetic field and mechanical loading conspire to generate sufficiently large compression along the long axes of the fibers, which can in turn be relieved by collective rotation of the fibers within their respective domains. Making use of multi-layered structures, the rank-1 convexification of the magneto-elastic energy will be computed, thus leading to an upper bound for the "quasi-convexification" or "relaxation" of the energy in the "post-bifurcation" regime. Attempts will then be made to show that the rank-1 convexification is polyconvex and therefore quasi-convex. The resulting models will be used to explore the parameter space of microstructural variables (e.g., fiber volume fraction and aspect ratio) for enhanced magnetostriction and other coupled magneto-elastic properties (e.g., field-dependent moduli).

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magneto-active elastomers (MAEs) are composite materials consisting of nearly rigid, magnetically susceptible particles embedded in a soft, magnetically insensitive elastomer matrix. They exhibit field-dependent strains and changes in stiffness. However, the strains that have been achieved experimentally to date are still relatively small (of the order of 1 percent). The reason for these small strains can be traced back to the dipolar nature of the forces between particles. Large particle concentrations are required to generate strong forces, but large concentrations also lead to large overall stiffness for the composite material, which, in turn, tends to reduce the overall strain. Generating large actuation strains and stresses in MAEs for successful application as "artificial muscles" require novel strategies. In this project, we investigated the possible development of macroscopic instabilities in certain classes of MAEs with aligned short-fiber microstructures, and explored their post-instability response. It was found that the onset of such instabilities can lead under certain conditions to the development of "domain" mesostructures with "soft modes" of deformation, which can then be excited by externally applied magnetic field to produce large magnetostriction (i.e., magnetically controlled deformations). 

The development of constitutive models for MAEs undergoing such field-generated instabilities required the development and use of several powerful and sophisticated mathematical tools. Thus,  nonlinear homogenization methods were used to generate estimates for the macroscopic response before the onset of any instabilities. To simplify the analysis, this was first accomplished for simple laminates made up of alternating layers of two different magneto-elastic materials. We then considered composites with more general microstructures consisting of hard magnetic particles embedded in soft elastic materials (e.g., rubber), which required the application of a strategy for partially decoupling the magnetic and mechanical energies by means of a variational statement for the unknown particle rotations. The resulting constitutive models were then shown to lose macroscopic stability (strong ellipticity), leading to the formation of domain mesostructures. This phenomenon was found to occur when the magnetic field and mechanical fields were chosen to generate sufficiently large compression stresses along the long axes of the fibers, which could then be relieved by collective rotation of the fibers having alternating orientations within their respective domains. 

In mathematical terms, we constructed the "relaxation" (or quasi-convexification) of the energy in the post-bifurcation regime  (after the onset of any instabilities), which is known to correspond to the development of domain microstructures. For the layered composites, this was accomplished by first constructing  an upper bound for the magneto-elastic energy by means of the so-called the rank-1 convexification of the energy, and then showing that the rank-1 convexification is polyconvex (in an appropriately generalized sense) and therefore quasi-convex. The resulting relaxed models were used to explore the parameter space of microstructural variables (e.g., fiber volume fraction and aspect ratio) for enhanced magnetostriction and other coupled magneto-elastic properties. For more general microstructures, it was possible to make more limited progress, due to the complex calculations required. However, the feasibility for the general approach was demonstrated and general formulae were provided that can be used to estimate the relaxed energy of these more general MREs by means of numerical approaches using the computer. Thus, this research has led to the development of highly efficient multi-scale, multi-physics modeling techniques of broad application that are capable of handling complex microstructures, coupled, strongly nonlinear response, microstructure evolution, and the possible development of instabilities.  From a more general perspective, these homogenization techniques have the potential to replace more traditional and less effective "continuum mechanics" approaches in the development of constitutive theories for materials with complex microstructures and multi-functional responses.

The broader impacts resulting from this work include the training and mentoring of several graduate students, including students from under-represented groups. In particular, the graduate student supported by this grant successfully completed his PhD in Applied Math and Computational Science at Penn and is now a Senior Research Engineer at the Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University. In addition, the mathematical tools developed in this work will become part of a graduate-level course that the PI teaches at Penn on Composite Materials, as well as become part of a book that is being written on this subject. In addition, several papers were published, and presentations and seminars given in conferences and universities around the world, by the PI and his students. We expect that the work developed under this grant will eventually translate into corresponding progress for the understanding of other smart material systems, such as electro-active composites and chemically activated systems, including skeletal muscle. Therefore, the work is relevant for a vast array of current and future applications, including active vibration damping,  energy conversion, robotic grasping, and prosthetics and other devices.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2020
Modified by: Pedro Ponte Castaneda
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Magneto-active elastomers (MAEs) are composite materials consisting of nearly rigid, magnetically susceptible particles embedded in a soft, magnetically insensitive elastomer matrix. They exhibit field-dependent strains and changes in stiffness. However, the strains that have been achieved experimentally to date are still relatively small (of the order of 1 percent). The reason for these small strains can be traced back to the dipolar nature of the forces between particles. Large particle concentrations are required to generate strong forces, but large concentrations also lead to large overall stiffness for the composite material, which, in turn, tends to reduce the overall strain. Generating large actuation strains and stresses in MAEs for successful application as "artificial muscles" require novel strategies. In this project, we investigated the possible development of macroscopic instabilities in certain classes of MAEs with aligned short-fiber microstructures, and explored their post-instability response. It was found that the onset of such instabilities can lead under certain conditions to the development of "domain" mesostructures with "soft modes" of deformation, which can then be excited by externally applied magnetic field to produce large magnetostriction (i.e., magnetically controlled deformations). The development of constitutive models for MAEs undergoing such field-generated instabilities required the development and use of several powerful and sophisticated mathematical tools. Thus, nonlinear homogenization methods were used to generate estimates for the macroscopic response before the onset of any instabilities. To simplify the analysis, this was first accomplished for simple laminates made up of alternating layers of two different magneto-elastic materials. We then considered composites with more general microstructures consisting of hard magnetic particles embedded in soft elastic materials (e.g., rubber), which required the application of a strategy for partially decoupling the magnetic and mechanical energies by means of a variational statement for the unknown particle rotations. The resulting constitutive models were then shown to lose macroscopic stability (strong ellipticity), leading to the formation of domain mesostructures. This phenomenon was found to occur when the magnetic field and mechanical fields were chosen to generate sufficiently large compression stresses along the long axes of the fibers, which could then be relieved by collective rotation of the fibers having alternating orientations within their respective domains. In mathematical terms, we constructed the "relaxation" (or quasi-convexification) of the energy in the post-bifurcation regime (after the onset of any instabilities), which is known to correspond to the development of domain microstructures. For the layered composites, this was accomplished by first constructing an upper bound for the magneto-elastic energy by means of the so-called the rank-1 convexification of the energy, and then showing that the rank-1 convexification is polyconvex (in an appropriately generalized sense) and therefore quasi-convex. The resulting relaxed models were used to explore the parameter space of microstructural variables (e.g., fiber volume fraction and aspect ratio) for enhanced magnetostriction and other coupled magneto-elastic properties. For more general microstructures, it was possible to make more limited progress, due to the complex calculations required. However, the feasibility for the general approach was demonstrated and general formulae were provided that can be used to estimate the relaxed energy of these more general MREs by means of numerical approaches using the computer. Thus, this research has led to the development of highly efficient multi-scale, multi-physics modeling techniques of broad application that are capable of handling complex microstructures, coupled, strongly nonlinear response, microstructure evolution, and the possible development of instabilities. From a more general perspective, these homogenization techniques have the potential to replace more traditional and less effective "continuum mechanics" approaches in the development of constitutive theories for materials with complex microstructures and multi-functional responses. The broader impacts resulting from this work include the training and mentoring of several graduate students, including students from under-represented groups. In particular, the graduate student supported by this grant successfully completed his PhD in Applied Math and Computational Science at Penn and is now a Senior Research Engineer at the Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University. In addition, the mathematical tools developed in this work will become part of a graduate-level course that the PI teaches at Penn on Composite Materials, as well as become part of a book that is being written on this subject. In addition, several papers were published, and presentations and seminars given in conferences and universities around the world, by the PI and his students. We expect that the work developed under this grant will eventually translate into corresponding progress for the understanding of other smart material systems, such as electro-active composites and chemically activated systems, including skeletal muscle. Therefore, the work is relevant for a vast array of current and future applications, including active vibration damping, energy conversion, robotic grasping, and prosthetics and other devices.
